DOC.HEAD: Call-In Survey Reveals Insecurity Over Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Workers feel insecure about their jobs and worry about layoffs in 1990, an informal call-in survey found, and an economic forecaster called it ``a very reasonable fear.'' About 600 of the 1,100 people who phoned in during a one-day survey were employed and 44 percent of them felt 1990 would bring significant changes for them in the workplace, said the survey's sponsor, Challenger, Gray & Christmas, an international job-counseling firm. Workers calling from as far away as Los Angeles, Detroit, Boston and Philadelphia said they worried about losing jobs to hostile takeovers, economic decline and cutbacks and foreign competition, Challenger said. ``People are worried that the security they once had ... is no longer there,'' John Challenger, sales and marketing director for the Chicago-based company, said Friday. The survey, conducted Thursday, is unscientific because it reflects only the views of people who called in, rather than a random sampling of the population. An economist at the WEFA Group, a consulting firm in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., said the survey's results could be expected. ``It's a very reasonable fear,'' said John Hagens, who specializes in short-term economic forecasting. ``There will be more cuts in 1990 and fewer new hires than we've had in '89 and '88 and '87.'' ``For the first time in many years, the national unemployment rate will rise,'' Hagens predicted in a telephone interview. The adjusted national unemployment rate stood at 5.4 percent in November. Layoffs and early retirement plans in blue-chip companies like American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and International Business Machines Corp. and throughout the computer and automobile industries are signals that growth in employment is slowing, Hagens said. He predicted employment growth in 1990 will be only 1.5 percent, about half the 1989 rate. Challenger, with 16 offices in the United States and Europe, counsels people who have been fired and referred by their former companies. Each year during the week after Christmas, the firm advertises its telephone number and opens phone lines to counsel individuals for free. The survey results are compiled from information the firm collects during the call-in. The majority, 59 percent, of the working callers to the survey were under 40 and earned an average of $30,000 to $50,000, said James Challenger, John's father and president of the company. About 58 percent of the workers also indicated they would be willing to leave their city to find new work, which shows Americans learned to enlarge the scope of their job search during the last recession, James Challenger said. Unemployed workers who called, 76 percent of whom were 30 or older, worried they won't be able to find jobs quickly in 1990 and sought tips on job hunting and interviewing, said Ann Marks, a consultant at the company. ``You hear real worry from people,'' Ms. Marks said. ``It's tough to be out of work any time, but especially during the holiday season.'' The average time a person went unemployed in 1989 was 3.2 months, she said, but 85 percent to 90 percent found equal or better paying jobs. Workers who find themselves unemployed in 1990 need to be extremely aggressive in the narrowing and highly competitive job market, Ms. Marks said. ``You've got to get plugging, go out and see the employers and call if they don't,'' she said.
